div.p: 1. V. Sunday. Walk round the Tyber Square.

Rode with Miss Mease, to the Unitarian Church, and heard Mr Little from Luke 11.28. “But he said, yea rather, blessed are they that hear the word of God and keep it.” The Communion service was performed, in which Miss Mease joined— Elizabeth Adams was also with us— Note from G. Sullivan to John, saying that he would come and dine with us— In the afternoon, I attended at St. John’s, Mr Hawleys Church, and heard a Mr Lee, from Isaiah 5.4.5.6. “What could have been done more to my vineyard, that I have not done in it? wherefore, when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?— And now go to: I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard: I will take away the hedge thereof, and it shall be eaten up; and break down the wall thereof; and it shall be trodden down:— And I will lay it waste: it shall not be pruned, nor digged; but there shall come up briers and thorns: I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.”— Neither the morning nor the afternoon discourse was occasional, upon the commencement of the year. G. Sullivan was there and came, dined and spent part of the Evening with us— Dr Watkins came also this Evening, and read to me the Address to the Columbian Institute which he is to deliver next Saturday. I freely remarked upon it— The Dr also told me that Dr Kent now a member of the House of Representatives, would to-morrow be elected Governor of Maryland, by the Legislature— Two expresses had been sent to him who arrived this morning; and he has been prevailed upon to accept, after having previously declined being a candidate.
2. VI. Walk to the Capitol—

Mr Wirt the Attorney General called soon after Breakfast— Mr Rush had written to him at Baltimore; requesting him if he could conveniently to come here; with a view to take his opinion upon several points of Law, which have arisen in the case of Edward Thompson’s failure, and the frauds at the Philadelphia Custom-House— Mr Wirt said he would be obliged to return on Wednesday to Baltimore. In the mean time he will give his opinion upon the questions propounded, here— The usual Visitation of the New-Year’s day, was made at this house from Noon till three O’Clock, and the crowd of company was said to have been greater than ever had been known before—amounting from two or three thousand persons. The greater portion of the members of both Houses of Congress were here; and formed only a small part of the company— The British and Mexican Ministers came, and the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires; but neither the Russian nor French Ministers, nor any persons of their Legations— They had applied last week to Mr Clay, the Secretary of State, suggesting their old objection to coming with the crowd, and proposed to come in State, another day; say to-morrow; which I explicitly declined; being unwilling to make two days of ceremony instead of one; and still more so to yield to their pretensions, which I think quite unreasonable. I desired Mr Clay to inform them, that if they were desirous of avoiding a crowd they might do so by coming before half past twelve, or about three. The Chevalier Huygens the Minister from the Netherlands came, after three, and left Cards, but did not come in— Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy came to my Cabinet after the throng had withdrawn, and left with me the Supplementary charges of Midshipman Van Dyke against Captain John Rodgers— He also read to me his draft of an Answer to Van Dyke refusing to arrest Rodgers and censuring the temper of the Charges. I suggested to him some alterations of the draft, to which he assented. He also left with me a list of names for our ships of war, frigates and Corvettes to be completed. I was until dinner time much fatigued with the ceremony of the morning. The Band of Musick
of the Marine Corps, enlivened the day while the company were here; and left something of depression after they were gone— Mr Lloyd, Senator from Massachusetts came and spent an hour of the Evening with me. He brought a large file of papers relating to the nomination of J. B. Swanton as Collector at Bath in Maine—among which were several private and confidential Letters to me, which had been first given inadvertently from my files to the Secretary of the Treasury, and then from him to Mr Lloyd; Chairman of the Committee to which the nomination had been referred— Mr Lloyd observed justly that they ought not to have been given to the Committee at all; and left the file with me to take off any of them as I should think proper— He left also a minute given him by the Comptroller, importing objection against the appointment of a Mister Miller, as Collector at Blakely Alabama, though his name had been sent to me from the Treasury Department for Nomination; and although I had delayed sending in for several days all the Treasury Nominations, to ascertain that all the individuals nominated were regular in their Accounts— Mr Lloyd spoke also to me of the Resolution offered to the Senate by Mr Branch; but, he said not drawn up by Branch; who was a mere tool in the hands of another man behind the curtain. He supposed the Resolution would be referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations, which would report it back and sustain it— He believed it would not pass; but would be laid on the table— It proceeded undoubtedly from a disposition unfriendly to me; but perhaps the positive manner in which I had expressed myself had given some handle to the construction which the Resolution gave to my words— Perhaps I might take occasion to send an explanation of my real meaning to the Senate— I said I had certainly no pretension to infallibility: that I may have expressed myself in terms susceptible of misconstruction, I could not deny, but in this case the misconstruction was so palpably erroneous that I could not think an explanation from me, necessary to expose it. Mr Branch had been compelled to add his own mistaken inference to my words, in order to make up the substance of a charge against me. He states me to have asserted, that which I did not assert— He calls upon the Senate to accuse, try and convict me, in secret inquisition, without hearing me in my defence; without even letting me know that there was a charge against me— If I must choose between the alternative of such a Resolution of the Senate recorded against me, or of resorting to the humiliating expedient of sending to the Senate an explanation of my own words, I thought I should prefer the last. Mr Lloyd admitted there was weight in these observations and I added that I found no article or clause in the Constitution of the United States, delegating the right or the power to define, limit or declare what are or are not the Constitutional powers of the President— He said again he believed the Resolution would not be adopted; but it would be well to be prepared for it when brought forward by the Committee of Foreign Relations— He repeated that Branch was only the vehicle by whom the Resolution was produced, that he was himself incapable either of drawing up the Resolution, or of sustaining it, in debate. In this I believe he was mistaken— Branch though a man of humble parts is quite capable of draughting such a resolution—and of sustaining it by some eloquence, though to a very minute extent.

div.p: 3. V:30. Walk to the Capitol Square.

Mr Mills called and had further Conversation with me respecting the Resolution offered to the Senate by Mr Branch. He says Branch told him that he did not propose moving the reference of it to the Committee of Foreign Relations— He said it was a plain proposition of matter of fact; concerning which every member could make up his own mind— Mills said he did not believe the Resolution would pass; it would either be laid on the table or a direct vote rejecting it might be obtained— I said the Senate might dispose of it as they should think proper, if they should not pass it— But if the Senate were to take an attitude of positive hostility to the Administration, I thought this was ground upon which the Executive would stand defensively stronger than perhaps any other that could be taken— A secret tribunal, or Inquisition of State, in which they constitute themselves accusers, triers, judges and Executioners against the President of the United States upon impeachable matters without hearing him, without even informing him that they are receiving charges against him. Mills said that the subject would not be called up for several days, in as much as Mr Branch had been suddenly called home by the illness or death of some near relation— Mr John Bailey called to recommend sundry persons to office— Mr Clay brought a written Note from the French Minister, the Baron de Mareuil, requesting that I would appoint a time when he could come and offer me his Congratulations on the new year; and present to me all the members of his Legation; which I declined— Mr Clay had prepared an answer, expressing much acknowledgment for the kindness of the Baron; but that no usage having warranted such a formality I did not feel justified to introduce it.— Mr Rush mentioned that Mr Samuel Harrison Smith had accepted the agency to go to Philadelphia, and investigate the transactions at the Custom House, in relation to the teas of Edward Thompson; and we had long Conversation about the Instructions to be given to Mr Smith for the execution of his trust— General Brown came, and spoke of the application of Major Worth of West Point, for a brevet upon his brevet—which I have declined granting. The General spoke also of the conflicting claims of Coll. King and of General Bissell to the vacant appointment of Colonel of the second Regiment of Infantry— I said that Bissells claim simply to be ordered upon duty, as if he had been without interruption in the army, could not be granted—but I had read his papers and for the vacant appointment thought he had made out a very strong case. Thirty odd years of constant service in the army—a rise from the ranks—distinguished good conduct on various occasions— I thought too General Scott had treated Bissell rather harshly— And whatever the misconduct of Bissell might have been, there was no evidence bringing it home to him— Brown said that of Scott’s proceedure he thought as I did; but of Bissell’s vicious conduct, particularly of his having ruined many young men in the army by gambling the testimony to him was so strong that he firmly believed it— Brown had sent me two or three days since a Letter from Genl. Scott, highly indignant at the appointment of Coll. Croghan as Inspector General— Scott’s Letter also mentioned that the Officers of the army, with him at New-York, were all excessively irritated at this appointment, and had talked of a meeting to shew their resentment which he Scott had prevented— Brown said they would not indulge themselves in any excess; but that such would be their feelings unanimously. Mr Daniel Brent brought some papers from the Department of State. Mr Southard read me the draft of his Answer to a Resolution from the House of Representatives, calling for information concerning the Sloop of War Boston, and enquiring whether she could not be employed to survey the Northwest Coast and to send Cannon to the Mouth of Columbia river— Evening spent in my cabinet writing.
4. VI. Walk to Capitol— Sun rose 7:21. Already making visibly Northern declination.

Mr Gurley, who is a member of the House of Representatives, from Louisiana, came with a request from the faculty of a College recently established in the interior of that State, that I would recommend them a President— They wished, the man to be a clergyman and a unitarian the Salary they promise to give him is three thousand dollars a year— They have already made the offer to Mr Holley, now President of the Transylvania University in Kentucky, and to Mr Pierpont a Clergyman of Boston; both of whom have declined— I told Mr Gurley I had been so long absent from my native State that the distinguished literary men of the age suitable for such an Office were scarcely known to me— I advised him to consult Mr Everett— The Secretary of the Senate Mr Lowry came twice, with Resolutions of the Senate and Confirmations of appointments— Edwards and Stephenson are members of the House from Pennsylvania, who came to recommend Mr Markley another member of the House, for the appointment of Collector at Philadelphia, if as was much expected a new appointment to that office should be made. Mr Burges came to introduce Mr Martin a Citizen of Rhode Island— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster-General came to consult me concerning the appointment of a Postmaster at New-Orleans in the place of Coll. Croghan, appointed Inspector General of the army— Several persons are recommended to him, among whom Mr Fulwar Skipwith. But he shewed me two Letters from General Jackson, extremely severe upon Skipwith, and charging him with having in 1814 while President of the Senate of Louisiana, been prepared to capitulate to the British, and having thwarted to the utmost of his power the General’s arrangements of defence I had been favourable to the appointment of Skipwith; but these Letters staggered greatly my good will towards him— I gave no opinion to Mr M’Lean in his favour. Mr Rush brought a Letter from Mr C. J. Ingersoll, concerning the demur in the Senate to his re-appointment as District Attorney— He seems to be much agitated and alarmed; goes through the list of the whole Senate, pointing out every individual’s dispositions, as he expects they will be towards him. He enclosed three Notes to individual Senators to be delivered to them if Mr Rush should think it advisable, requesting their good offices, and daily correspondence with him concerning his case But I thought it would be best for him that those notes should not be delivered. I promised to speak to Mr Van Buren myself for him— Mr Blunt was here and borrowed Jenkinson’s collection of Treaties— Also made inquiries when the Commission of the District Attorney for the Southern district of New-York would expire. Genl. S. Smith came with a Letter from Jos. W. Patterson declining to serve as a Bank Director, and two other Letters recommending the appointment of John M’Kim in his place. I asked him as to the character of Jacob Adams. He said he would not be as acceptable as M’Kim— General Smith said also much to me of our commercial relations with Portugal, of which he gave a historical account; from a period even preceding our revolution; and proposed to draw up a memoir of it in writing to which I assented. He was also very anxious that the Mission to the Netherlands should be raised from the rank of Charge d’Affaires to that of a Minister Plenipotentiary, which I thought could not be accomplished. Mr Southard brought and read to me several Letters from Captain Warrington.
Johnson Hellen left us this day, and returned to Rockville— My Sons John and Charles dined at Mr Clays— I sent a Message with two nominations of paymasters of the army—and received a Resolution from the House of Representatives, calling for a list of all the members of Congress appointed to Offices since the existence of the Government— General Robert Swartwout called this evening to take leave— Going for New-York to-morrow morning. He said he was making progress in the Settlement of his Accounts— He also made some observations concerning the state of politics in New-York; and friendly professions to which no reply from me was necessary.
5. V:30. Walk to Capitol Square.— Sun rose 7:20.

Cook came to speak about the Leasing of Lead mines in Missouri and Illinois. Mr Bell, a Senator from New-Hampshire, to mention the desire of a Lieutt. Coll. M’Neal, who is a Coll. by Brevet, to obtain another Brevet. Thinks he has been neglected, and hopes for promotion— He is a native of New-Hampshire— I intimated to Governor Bell, as gently as I could the difficulty of granting brevets in time of peace; and particularly brevets upon brevets— Their obnoxiousness to Congress, and to the Public; which he admitted— He spoke also of the Resolution offered by Mr Branch; of its unfairness and injustice; and said it had been very offensive to many members of the Senate— He added that he believed Vice-President Calhoun to be the secret instigator of it, and of all the opposition to the Administration in the Senate— He said he had remarked the disingenuousness of Branch’s Resolution, in making his own misconstruction of my words, a part of those words themselves, in order to make them exceptionable— And added that upon my words as they were, he could have charged nothing improper. Mr Mallary came to speak of the appointment of a Collector at Alburgh— He was much displeased with Governor Van Ness, and Mr Hyde, for attempting to supplant Fisk, and said Meech had violated his agreement with him, in coming separately and recommending Hyde to me— He said Hyde was an electioneering tool of Van Ness; and that Van Ness was endeavouring to supplant Seymour here in the Senate— Seymour himself had intimated as much to me, and Bradley, who said he believed Van Ness would succeed— Mallary was much incensed at all this—but I told him I should make no nomination to the office, till I should hear further from him— Dr Kent has been elected Governor of the State of Maryland, by the Legislature, and came to take leave— Going off to Annapolis to-morrow— I told him I had not the heart to congratulate him— He will be a severe and I fear irreparable loss, to the Administration in the House of Representatives, though as Governor of Maryland he will be in a station of still greater influence, to befriend us. He has been one of my steadiest and most efficient friends— Mr Rush came with a draft of Instructions to S. H. Smith, who is going to Philadelphia, to investigate the facts relating to the frauds of Edward Thomson upon the Custom House— Mr Hammond the Agent from the State of New-York, left with me a copy of a Letter from him to the Secretary of War, relating to a claim of that State against the Union, upon a settlement of Accounts relating to the War— The Letter contained an elaborate argument, which the documents appeared to support. I told Hammond, I would read with attention his papers— Mr Clay called to speak of Resolutions one of the House of Representatives, calling for a list of all the members of Congress, appointed to Executive Offices, since the Institution of the Government and one from the Senate, asking for a communication in confidence of the Treaties between the South-American States relating to the meeting at Panama, and any other documents tending to shew its expediency. Mr A. Dickins came to mention the final arrangements of the Columbian Institute, for the
delivery of the Address by Dr. Watkins on Saturday— He also spoke to me of the expediency of a new organization at the Treasury Department; of a separate Bureau for the business of the Custom-Houses; like that of the Land Office; and that he might be placed at the head of it— I advised him to consult about it with Mr Rush, and told him I should be disposed to do for him whatever might be in my power with propriety— We had company to dine— W. Armstrong jr.Joseph Blunt, Daniel Brent, James Clarke, B. W. Crowninshield, Mrs. and Miss Mary, Powhatan Ellis, Christopher Hughes, Rollin C. Mallary, Dudley Marvin, Thomas Newton, Henry H. Ross, John Sloane and Miss, Peleg Sprague, Martin Van Buren, Joseph Vance, Hugh L. White, Lewis Williams, and John Wurts, in all, with the family and Miss Mease 27— Tristam Burges and Miss, Governor Cass, General and Mrs Gaines, Ralph I. Ingersoll, John Long, Louis M’Lane and Mrs. S. L. Southard and Mrs Robert Swartwout, Aaron Ward, Henry Wilson, and Levi and Mrs Woodbury were invited and came not— I spoke to Mr Van Buren, and to Judge White about C. J. Ingersoll, and they promised to interest themselves in his favour. Van Buren said he had been fully acquainted four years ago, with the affair now brought up again, against him— He had then thought it quite indiscreet; and still thought it so; but upon the whole not sufficient cause for rejecting him— He thought well of Ingersoll though he believed him to be a very selfish person— White spoke of him only in general terms.
6. V:30. Capitol Square— Sun rose 7:20.

General Van Rensselaer came to speak of the long Eastern lower Hall of the Presidential House which remains unfurnished— The crowd of New-Year’s day overflowed into it, and it was seen in its nakedness by many Members of Congress— Van Rensselaer has since offered a Resolution in the house proposing a Committee to inquire and report upon the propriety of finishing and furnishing the public buildings. He is Chairman of the Committee, and enquired what I thought would be the cost of furnishing the Eastern Hall— I asked him to excuse me from having any opinion about it. He intimated that it might not be necessary to furnish it in the same style of expence as the other company rooms of the House— And enquired how it was in similar Halls of European Palaces— I told him that so far as I had seen such Halls they were very variously furnished. Some magnificently—others with old and even decayed furniture—of which I had seen more in Palaces than in any other buildings— He said the Committee would perhaps be glad to look over the house; to which I very readily assented; and he observed he would be glad to speak of it to Mrs Adams. Mr White the Delegate from the Territory of Florida, came to recommend certain persons as Custom-house Officers at Apalachicola; and one or two other places— He spoke also of his project for cutting a Canal, and even a ship channel across the Isthmus of Florida, which Mr Webster has introduced for him into the House of Representatives— He was highly gratified at this, and said Webster was himself a Host— I told him I hoped Congress would engage in this undertaking; and should do every thing in my power to ensure its success— J. S. Barbour came to recommend John P. Duval, for some Office, here, or in Florida where his brother is Governor— Barbour mentioned to me that his kinsman the Secretary of War was exceedingly distressed at this time, having a small boy suddenly
seized, and very dangerously ill, and having also just received information of the death of his Sister, Mrs. Gray, by suicide— He said he had never seen him so much overcome with affliction— Thomas Thruston brought from the Department of State, a Letter from Mr Howland of Alexandria, to D. Brent, demanding with great vehemence his release from imprisonment— Upon examination of the papers, I had some doubts whether he ought to be released, and concluded to take the advice of the Secretary of the Treasury before deciding upon the case— Mr Lowry came with four Resolutions of the Senate confirming nominations, and Mr Brown, a teacher, with a new Grammar, and a new theory of syntax, quite his own— He wished to have my opinion concerning it, which I declined giving; not having time sufficient for the examination—and also upon the general principle, of giving no commendatory Certificates, which the Presidents of the United States have always observed— Eve Alone.
7. VI. Warm, damp fog.— Tooth-ache, and shooting pains in the face.

Sullivan came for a morning visit; and with a warm recommendation of Blunt, that he might occasionally be employed as assistant Counsel to the District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, Tillotson—he repeated what he had told me before, that he himself was going to settle in the practice of the bar at New-York— The Military Committee of the House of Representatives at the head of which is Major Hamilton of South-Carolina, have now reported a Bill upon the Massachusetts Claim, entirely different from that which at the recommendation of Mr Monroe they had reported two Years ago— It was then in substance for the whole claim: it is now only for that part of it which is not affected by the Constitutional stumbling block which Governor Strong of Massachusetts had interposed— a part which the Executive of the Union could not lawfully reject— William King of Maine, attempted to make of this claim an electioneering Engine for Crawford—but he disclosed his purpose prematurely to Sullivan, who by obtaining the Agency for the State of Massachusetts, defeated King’s Crawfordite intrigue; but threw the whole interest into the hands of Calhoun— He by prevailing upon Mr Monroe to decide inflexibly upon sending the whole claim to Congress, kept it in fact in his own hands— It went of course to the Military Committee; the chairman of which, Hamilton, was devoted to him— By the President’s warm recommendation of the claim to Congress; and by a corresponding Bill, promptly reported by the Military Committee, Calhoun kept Sullivan in the undoubting belief, that he was himself entirely friendly to the claim, and that it would be admitted in its whole extent— In the mean time he secured Sullivan’s ardent and zealous support to his election as Vice-President, which by Sullivan’s intimacy with me; and by his influence over many of the Massachusetts Electors, and particularly Mr Winthrop, Sullivan’s father in Law, was very efficacious— It decided Calhoun’s Election— But during all this time, and through both Sessions of the last Congress, the Bill reported by the Military Committee was artfully kept suspended, and never passed— Now, the Military Committee report a totally different Bill; cutting off nearly two thirds of the claim; and the members avowing that they will oppose the admission of any part of it, to which the constitutional objection had been applied— Sullivan has been cruelly deceived, but his pride will not permit him to acknowledge it; perhaps not even to himself— He is however preparing to abandon the claim; and also his residence at Boston, where under his ill success, to return
would subject him to humiliation— Mr Rush came in with Letters from C. J. Ingersoll, from the Collector Steele, and from Edward Thomson— There is some disagreement between the District Attorney, and the Collector— Both need further Instructions, and Mr Rush is also preparing to despatch Mr S. H. Smith— He is also beginning to feel the consequence of attempting to reduce the permanent deposits in sundry banks— It will probably break most of them. They are now soliciting, imploring and threatening, to be relieved from the demand. I attended at eleven O’Clock the Meeting of the Columbian Institute at the Capitol— Met and walked thither with Wallenstein— At Noon the Society went in procession to the Hall of the House of Representatives, where an anniversary discourse was delivered by Dr Watkins. Very good matter, and well spoken— The house was thin— The Society returned afterwards to their room, and passed a vote, requesting a copy of the Discourse for the press: and then dispersed— Blunt walked home with me— I proposed the name of George Sullivan to be voted for as a corresponding member— The Society dined together at Williamson’s, but in pursuance of the established usage, I declined joining the party— After I returned home, Mr Clay came, concerning the Resolution of the Senate, requesting confidential communication of further papers relating to the Panama Mission— We agreed that it would be admirable to communicate the proposition made last Spring to the Russian Government, and the Correspondence which has ensued relating to it— The papers will be ready on Monday— Clay told me he had Letters from Mr Crittenden and Amos Kendall, both agreeing that if Crittenden’s Resolutions approving Clay’s conduct had been taken up they would have passed— Kendall says not without powerful opposition.— Eve much occupied.
8. V:30. Thick fog.—damp and warm— Shooting pains of tooth-ache.

Walk to the Capitol, and heard Bishop of Charleston—England—an Irishman— He read a few prayers; and then delivered an extemporaneous discourse; of nearly two hours duration; in defence of the Roman Catholic Church— Altogether conciliatory, and in the true Christian temper— He disclaimed all spirit of compulsion upon the Souls of men— Said that obedience was indeed required to that which was ascertained to be the will of God; but that was not the right of the Pope; but only of a general Council of all the Bishops— He disclaimed also all persecution, and commented with great ingenuity, upon a decree of a Council, issued in the fourteenth Century, authorizing the extermination of heretics, and absolving from their allegiance the subjects of Princes who should be backward in carrying the decree into execution— Even this atrocious Edict, he almost explained away— He closed by reading an admirable prayer— He came and spoke to me after the service, and said he would call and take leave of me to-morrow. The house was overflowing; and it was with great difficulty that I obtained a Seat— I called to see Mr Gaillard a Senator from South Carolina, whom I found severely ill-in-bed— With a fever, and bilious exudation like jaundice— I met there first N. Macon and W. N. Edwards of North-Carolina— And then R. Y. Hayne and James Hamilton of South-Carolina— I called also at Governor Barbour’s, but was told his child was so ill that he could receive no person— That the child was however a little better than the preceding days— I attended in the afternoon at the Presbyterian Church
and heard Mr Baker from John 9.4. “I must work the works of him that sent me while it is day: the night cometh, when no man can work.” Mr Baker laid great stress of warning and communication; upon the words “the night cometh.”— In the Evening at Dr Laurie’s Church I heard a Quaker woman from England, by the name of Elizabeth Robson, preach upwards of an hour from the words “How excellent is thy loving kindness, O God! therefore the children of men put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.” She did not name her text, but it was from Psalm 36.7— She was fluent, and had a vast collection of passages from Scripture, which she repeated with great ease; but she ran into a continual sing song of delivery. There was a man, and another woman with her in the pulpit. When she had finished her Sermon, after a short interval she knelt and made a short, but very fervent prayer— The house was much crowded— Many Members of Congress there— Mr Webster was here while I was out. I did not see him— Wrote an hour after returning home—
