div.p: 9. VI. Walk to the Capitol— Thick fog— Warm.

The day and evening were absorbed by these visitors— Mr Letcher came to testify to an account of a Mr Crittenden, Secretary to the Arkansas territory, for a claim of Salary from the 3d: of March 1819. when the Law constituting the territory passed, to the 4th. of July when the territorial Government was organized— Letcher himself, who had been at the same time appointed a judge of the same territory, had been allowed for the same charge, by the special order of Mr Monroe— Crittenden’s account had been brought to me for the order of allowance; but there was no proof that he had incurred the same expenses as Letcher. I had required such proof— Letcher now certified it personally, and I requested him to do it in writing, which he promised— Letcher spoke also of Kentucky Politics, and of Mr John Pope’s course both on the Presidential Election, and on the party-conflicts in Kentucky—with which he was not satisfied— Kellogg— Governor Barbour brought me a report, recommending the nomination of General Bissell, as Colonel of the second Regiment of Artillery— And the answer of the Georgia delegation to the enquiry made of them whether they would prefer a new Negotiation with the Creek Indians on the basis offered by them of a cession of Lands to the Chatahoochy, or to have the Treaty sent to Congress— Their answer is that they choose neither— Their Letter however is in a moderate, and not disrespectful tone— Blunt returned me the books he had borrowed—and recommended his brother for an appointment as a civil Engineer— Payton— Mr Markley a member of the House from Pennsylvania came and introduced General Porter, Agent for certain claims of that State. He recollected having seen me at Philadelphia, in October 1824 when General La Fayette was there. Mr Wurts came with Mr Richards a partner of the House of Lippincott’s, who brought a declaration of Edward Thompson, and Letters from J. Sergeant and H. Binney explaining certain circumstances in the conduct of the Lippincott’s which had appeared suspicious. They appeared to me thus far satisfactory; but I told Mr Richards we had taken the opinion of the Attorney General, who thought the Teas must be kept, for a decision by a judicial tribunal, whether they are not all answerable to the United States, for the whole
amount of the duties owed by Thompson— He said he was glad the decision of the Government was placed on that ground, as he felt more solicitous for the character of the house than for the property— But he said, the Teas were in some respect a perishable Article— If kept until the arrival of the Spring ships from China, they would lose three fourths of their price in the market. They had already lost much. He enquired if they could not be delivered over to the Lippincott’s on their giving bond with sufficient security to abide by the decision of the Court upon the question of the right of the United States to hold them— I said I thought this arrangement might be made without difficulty, it being suggested in the opinion of the Attorney-General himself— Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy read me the answer he had prepared to a Resolution offered by Mr Baylies, enquiring concerning the expense of sending the Sloop of War, Boston, lately launched to survey the Northwest Coast, and to send Cannon to the Mouth of Columbia river—which I approved— G. Sullivan and E. Everett were successively here in the Evening. Sullivan desponding upon the subject of his claim, and intending to settle in the practice of the law at New-York— Everett speaking of various objects now under the consideration of Congress— Among the rest of Hamilton’s Resolution to call for Papers relating to the proposed Mission to Panama. Hamilton couched his Resolution in words importing a disposition to blame—two days after making it he said that being informed that a Message would in due time be sent by the Executive to the house concerning it; he was willing his Resolution should lie on the table—reserving his right to call it up when he should see cause— Last Thursday he gave notice that he should call it up the next day; but he did not and has not yet— I told Everett that if he should call it up, it would be perhaps proper to urge its postponement from respectful deference to the Senate, to give them time to act, on the nominations now before them— With intimations that perhaps the Senate might disapprove of the Mission; in which case the house would have no occasion to act upon it at-all— I supposed this would bring Hamilton more out, and further disclose the views of the party of which he is the organ— He cannot keep their Counsel— This is apparently the first measure, in which the opposition are endeavouring to array themselves— They are bitter and rancorous, but are yet discordant among themselves— If they can be brought to combine.
10. V:30 Capitol Square.

Mr Mills, called and told me of the proceedings of the Committee of foreign Relations of the Senate; which produced the call for further communications in confidence— Tazewell whose conduct has been full of equivocations, said he wanted to see the Treaties between the South-American Republics concerning the Congress of Panama— To this Mills agreed— Then Tazewell wanted more confidential papers— Mills asked him to draw up a Resolution— No—he wished Mills to draw it up himself— Mills drew it accordingly; and when presented in Senate, Tazewell opposed its passage might and main. The Committee will report against the confirmation of the Mission— I sent to the
Senate this day the documents requested in Confidence— Also a List of Nominations and thirteen Indian Treaties— C. Hughes called to take leave; being upon his return to Baltimore. Mr Lathrop of Massachusetts, and Mr Robert Taylor of Virginia, both Members of the House, called to make a morning visit; and Mr Coleman of Salem, who has been several weeks at Baltimore; preaching at the Congregational Church there— He dined with us. Major Massias just from Charleston S.C. was also here; and Richard Maury with Matthew Maury, Son of our Consul at Liverpool— Mr W. S. Nicholls of Georgetown came likewise with a Letter of Introduction. Mr Rush, Secretary of the Treasury was with me part of the Morning— Mr Saml H Smith proceeded upon his Mission to Philadelphia on Sunday.
11. V. Walk to the Capitol.

Force was here, and I gave him directions for making up several volumes for Executive Records— He spoke of a Letter from Mitchell of Tennessee published in the Nashville Republican, and containing very severe remarks upon the Message to Congress. Mr William Hunter of Georgia, but originally from Pennsylvania came and set forth his claims and wishes to obtain an Office, in the Customs of in the Land-Office— Dr Lovell and Mr Baker for the Trustees of the Presbyterian Church came to request the assignment of a certain Square (N. 207) for a burying ground, for the members of that Church. They said that Mr Elgar, the Commissioner of the Public Buildings objected that it was too near the central part of the City; but added that he would assign it to them, if I would so direct him— They left the application with me, to be acted upon in future. Mr Maguire came again to represent his poverty and his wants which are distressing. Mr Ward a Representative from a district in the State of New-York came to solicit in favour of William A. Wever heretofore a Lieutenant in the Navy cashiered by the sentence of a Court Martial, for malversation. He has a wife and children; and has been residing in Mr Ward’s district where they are all esteemed and beloved, and a universal sympathy is felt for them— It is hard to resist such appeals to compassion and humanity: but I told Mr Ward I had no authority to restore Mr Wever to the Navy. This is only way that I can meet such benevolent importunities; and even to this I find it sometimes difficult to adhere— Mr Adlum came to desire me to take some more of his wines— He made last year about seven hundred gallons; and wishes for the future to confine his cultivation chiefly to the Catawba grape— He puts both sugar and brandy in small quantities into his wines, which are so small, that they cannot perserve themselves from fermentation— Mrs Adams had this evening her third drawing-room, which was less crowded than the two former. D. P. Cook was here about half an hour before it began; and told me, Mr Mangum of North-Carolina, this day in a speech on the Bill before the House for appointing three additional judges of the Supreme Court, had given me a scoring— He had also indulged himself in reflections upon the State of Illinois, for which he Cook should give him his own in return— The Speaker J. W. Taylor stayed an hour after the rest of the company were gone— And spoke of Hamilton of South-Carolina’s sally at him, for presenting to the House a Memorial from a Crazy Man in France, who invited Congress to destroy all
the States which should refuse the emancipation of Slaves. Hamilton was not countenanced in his fit of chivalry; but Taylor said he had notice that a more formal attack upon him was intended, and by more formidable adversaries— He was told that a person of far more consideration and talents than Hamilton, and of the South-Carolina delegation, had spoken of this incident as proof of a fixed determination of the present administration to emancipate the Southern Slaves— He spoke also of Hamilton’s Resolution to call for the Papers relating to the Panama Mission— I said I believed it would be best to keep it alive; but if he called it up soon to put it off, and bring him out in his Hotspur vein till he shall disclose more of the secret views of his party. I told Taylor I believed the Message concerning the Panama Mission, must be a confidential one—to which he assented.

George Johnson came to enquire, if I had read some papers which he had left with my Son John: but I had not. Dr Watkins came and mentioned an attack upon me, published in the Richmond Enquirer, in numbers under the title of Political Disquisitions by W. B. Giles— He alludes to confidential communications between him and me in 1808. which he grossly misrepresents, then to his defence of me in December 1809. against an attack of T. Pickering in the Senate of the United States after I had resigned my Seat there: and he now solemnly revokes all that he said at that time in defence of me: declares his conviction that personal aggrandizement is the only motive of my conduct, and that I have taken Caesar for my model. All this had been produced in his mind by my Message which has produced a Crisis involving the liberty and happiness of all future ages— And he threatens some dreadful disclosure concerning me— Doctor Watkins enquired if it would be proper to take any notice of these publications— I said not at present— It would be more advisable to wait for his threatened disclosure. He could tell nothing true of me, of which I could ever have reason to be ashamed and if he should resort to falsehood, as to some extent he already has, my defence will not be difficult, and he can expose no one but himself— Mr M’Kean, member of the House from Pennsylvania came and introduced Mr Catlin a Citizen of that State— Mr Rush spoke of the case of C. J. Ingersoll—of the Collector of Apalachicola, and of Mr George Hay— The nominations of Ingersoll and Hay are suspended still in the Senate. Ingersoll’s explanatory Statement has been furnished to Mr Findlay and seen by some others of the Senators— Mr George Hay was commissioned during the recess as judge of the Eastern District of Virginia; and since the Commencement of the Session has been nominated to the Senate In one of Mr Giles’s Disquisitions he has charged Hay with being a defaulter; and Hay published an answer to this charge, admitting that he had some old accounts unsettled at the Treasury— That if a claim that he had for certain allowances should be admitted, there would be a balance due to him— If they should be rejected there would be a small balance due from him, which he would pay in less than 22 hours— Upon the appearance of this Letter of his own the nomination of him was referred to the judiciary committee of the Senate, and a correspondence with him has commenced both by the
Secretary and the first Comptroller of the Treasury— Mr Rush had with him and read to me the Letters— George Sullivan and Mr Bailey were here in the Evening and conversed upon various topics of political interest.

The Secretary of War, brought me a voluminous manuscript; being a Letter addressed to him by James Merriwether, one of the Commissioners on the part of the United States who made the Treaty with the Creeks last February; and now a member of Congress from Georgia— It is a defence of himself against charges contained in the Report of Major Andrews upon Crowell’s case— Governor Barbour said he had made one effort more to prevail upon the Creek deputation, to cede by a new Treaty all their Lands in Georgia; and Governor Cass, who understands the management of Indians has gone upon an excursion with Poethle Yeholo, and some others of the deputation to Baltimore— Lowry, the Secretary of the Senate, brought me three Resolutions of that body, confirming Nominations— Mr Lloyd came and spoke of several subjects in consideration before the Senate; particularly of Mr Branch’s Resolution, and of the nomination, to Panama. Branch is now absent and his Resolution lies for the time on the table— Lloyd said the Panama Nominations, he believed would be confirmed; by a small majority. But there would be a long, and elaborate report against it by the Committee of foreign Relations; written by Mr Tazewell, and it would be long and strenuously debated in the Senate— Mr Tucker introduced Mr Bonnycastle who is one of the Professors of the new Virginian University from Europe— Mr Coleman came to take leave—about returning to-morrow to Baltimore, and after the end of the Month to Salem— Wickliffe came to make some enquiries about an application for a marine Hospital at Louisville in Kentucky, and Hendricks about some appointment— Hunter was here to solicit a place, and gave me some account of his life— Mr Wever the cashiered Lieutenant came and implored an appointment—to be restored to his place in the Navy; or to be nominated anew to the Senate—or, some office in civil life to give him and his dependent family bread.— These appeals to Mercy and compassion are torturing— W. Findlay the Senator from Pennsylvania came to express a hope that the Collector at Philadelphia, Steele, might not be dismissed hastily— Said he was an old revolutionary Officer; always a warm Republican—generally known as a man of strict integrity; and if in the fraudulent removal of Thompson’s Teas there had been on his part some want of vigilance, and nothing more could be suspected of him, allowance should be made for his years and the infirm state of his health— I told Mr Findlay that all these things had been considered; that I should not hastily remove Mr Steele—that Mr Saml. H. Smith was gone to Philadelphia to investigate as well as we could authorise him to do all the facts; and I should act finally upon his Report. With this, Mr Findlay declared himself to be well satisfied— I asked him if he had made up his mind upon the case of C. J. Ingersoll— He said he did not wish to push the matter further; but he was told there was another, and stronger charge against Ingersoll, the evidence of which was expected here— Of this I knew nothing; and had not before heard.
Mr Southard came upon some of the business of the Navy Department. Mrs Southard has been for several days, and continues very ill— We had company to dine. R. G. Amory, Dudley Chase, John Cocke, John Davis, Clement and Miss Dorsey. H. W. Dwight, Edward and Mrs Everett, Genl. E. P and Mrs Gaines, W. H. Harrison, Richard Hines, Mr Hunter, Jeromus Johnson, Joseph Lecompte, G. E Mitchell, Benjamin and Mrs Ruggles, James Strong, Alexander and Mrs Thompson, Ebenezer Tucker, and Nicholas Van Dyke— With the family 31. at table. William Addams, Ratliff Boon, Governor Cass, Vernon H. Dorsey, Nicoll Fosdick, Nathaniel Macon, and Elisha Whittlesey were invited, but came not.— Evening occupied in signing Land-grants, Tuscaloosa, Alabama. 170.

I had in the morning declined allowing a claim of Genl. Harrison for Extra Services, in 1811—which he had not made at the time; but bethought himself of just now. He alledged an allowance of the same kind, by special order of Mr Monroe, to Governor Edwards of Illinois— But I knew Mr Monroe had constantly rejected a like claim by Genl. Hull— Governor Barbour said he believed he could direct the allowance of it himself—to which I told him I should not object.
14. V. Capitol Hill Bridge

Morgan is the Quaker of Georgetown, who petitioned to be discharged from imprisonment, on Execution against him for a debt due to the U.S. I referred his Petition to the District Attorney, who reported favourably upon it, and I this day signed the order for his discharge. Brown was Captain of a Revenue Cutter from which Gustavus Harrison was removed and to which he was lately restored— Brown being thereby displaced now applies for employment, with strong recommendations— Mr Rowan introduced Mr Pinkham, as a person from Kentucky— Mr Brent came for the order to discharge Morgan; and Slade afterwards called to enquire by what authority I gave it— He thought it was a case within the powers of remission granted to the Secretary of the Treasury. I read to him the provisions of that Statute; and also those of the Act giving the power of remission to P.U.S. in cases to which the powers of the Secretary of the Treasury do not extend, and satisfied him that this was one of those cases— Barbour and Ashley came for a morning visit; as did G. Blake and Mr Jaudon, who have just arrived, to attend the approaching Session of the Supreme Court. Mills brought me a Memorial signed by a number of Merchants in Boston, New-York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore, interested in claims upon the Government of the Netherlands, and praying for the appointment of a full Minister, as they term it, to that Court; meaning a Minister Plenipotentiary. I told Mills, that I had no doubt this was a manoeuvre of Christopher Hughes—to get his rank and emoluments raised— Mills told me also that the Committee of Foreign Relations had determined to Report against the Panama Mission, and Tazewell was to write an elaborate Report against it— Mr Gaillard’s illness had prevented him from attending the Committee; so that Mills had been alone in Committee in favour of the Mission— My Sons John and Charles, dined this day at Mr Rush’s, and there was an Evening party at the French Ministers attended by them, and by Mary Hellen—
15. V:30. Read Psalms 25.26.27.28.— Note especially 27.14.

Omitted my usual walk before Sunrise, and read with special and cheering consolation the Psalms above noted— Heard in the Morning Mr Little from 2. Timothy 4.6.7.8. “For I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand— I have fought a good fight, I have finished my Course, I have kept the faith: Henceforth there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness which the Lord, the righteous judge shall give me at that day: and not to me only, but unto all them also that love his appearing.” And I perceived in the text still more than in the discourse, the overwhelming power of the unquenchable Spirit of martyrdom— In the afternoon I heard at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley from Philippians 4.19. [“]But my God shall supply all your need, according to his riches in Glory by Christ Jesus—” Mr Little gave notice of an evening service, which I did not attend— Evening laboriously employed.
16. VI. Walk to Capitol Square.

Dickins came concerning the allowance of a claim of Crittenden, Secretary of the Arkansas Territory— I gave him the certificate of Mr Letcher, upon which the allowance is to be made— Mr Hammond the Agent for the State of New-York came to take leave. I told him I had read with great attention the papers he had left with me, and thought there was great weight in his argument, upon the only item of which he desired the revision. But the Secretary of War, upon examination had found that the decision of Mr Calhoun upon that item, had been made with all the documents before him, which Mr Hammond had believed to have been subsequently produced. Under these circumstances, we could not reverse the decision of Mr Calhoun, but as there were other items upon the claim, which were to be submitted to Congress, this would properly go before them at the same time. Governor Barbour in speaking of this affair to me some days since, seemed to doubt whether I ought to have received these papers from Hammond— I said I thought it my duty to hear every man who asked of me a hearing; and to read all papers which any person presented to me; but that my decisions upon them must be through the Departments; and as their Heads advise— Captain Warrington, Dr White, a Member from Duchess County New York and his brother were visitors— Mr Clay spoke of despatches, of very recent date received from Mr Poinsett the Minister to Mexico, from which it appears that the Expedition against Cuba is postponed— Mr Clay spoke also of the appointment to be made of a Chargé d’Affaires to Peru, and gave me a recommendation of General Adair of Kentucky for that office; in which however he did not join— He warmly urged the appointment of Henry R Warfield member of the last Congress from Maryland— To this however there are weighty objections— General Brown came to enquire if I should have any objection to the repeal of the Law by which appointments in the staff of the army are authorised to be made from persons not in the army. He said there was a Resolution to that effect now before the House of Representatives; and he wished to know my Sentiments concerning it, to determine him whether to take an interest in its success or not— I told him that I was willing it should have its fair chance with Congress— I should exercise no influence against it. The Resolution had evidently been brought in with a view to set a mark of reprobation upon the recent appointment of Coll. Croghan— It could not be expected that I should encourage or give countenance to that which was intended for censure upon my own Act— But I should excite no opposition to it— I was not tenacious of the power of selecting, and if Congress should think proper to
restrict it I should readily acquiesce— The General spoke of the appointment of Coll. Croghan again with much sensibility— Said it had been altogether unexpected to him. A thing he believed without example, in any service. I said I much regretted that it should so have affected him— That I had assured him repeatedly, that it was without any unkind intention towards him— That I was bound to act according to the advice deliberately given me by the Heads of Departments in the Affairs of their Offices, and that the Act, whether correct or not was done and could not be recalled— I was willing Congress should proceed upon the Resolution, with a full consideration of what I had done in that case; and should if they pleased find in it a motive, for limiting the appointments in future. But this was all I could say— The General declared that he would take no further concern in the matter— Mr Verplanck spent part of the Evening with us below.
17. V:30. Capitol Square. Sun rose 7:13. Fahrenheit 24

Sherburne came to solicit an appointment as a purser in the Navy; and to represent his extreme distress and that of his wife and five children in consequence of his dismission from the Office of a Clerk in the Navy Department. He left with me a Letter of solicitation to that effect. Cook, borrowed the Volume containing the narrative of Lewis and Clarke’s Expedition— He said that Louis M’Lane and A. Stevenson, speaking of the transmission to the House of Representatives of Mr Jefferson’s Message of 18. Jany 1805. said they considered it a very disgraceful transaction: and M’Lane said that the only way in which I was possessed of a copy of Mr Jefferson’s Message, was by my Diary, and taking privately a copy of it, as a member of the Senate when the Message was sent in— I told Cook that I knew not what those Gentlemen meant by denominating the transaction disgraceful— I was not aware of any thing in it which could even be justly called improper. Nor did I know whence Mr M’Lane drew his information— That I had not been in the Senate in January 1803. when this Message of Mr Jefferson was sent and I told him how I had found it on the Records of the Senate, while my own Message to Congress was preparing, and the impression it had made on all the members of the Administration when I read it to them. We were interrupted and Cook left me, but told my Sons, that A. Stevenson further said that since my Message the excitement against the General Government in Virginia was great, and universal. That opinions there had before then been divided; but now the whole State would move in one solid column— And he read a part of a Letter to him from a person in Richmond, quoting Extracts from Letters written by Mr Jefferson, and Mr Madison denouncing the doctrines of the Message in the most emphatic terms— Thomas called to speak to me of the Panama Mission— Said that the Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate had made a long and ingenious report against it—which would this day be printed— That he did not know how the vote in Senate would go—he believed there would be a majority to confirm the nomination. The minority however would be large, though he would do all in his power to
make it smaller— He did not know what the impression of the Report had been upon the members of the Senate— He was afraid it would induce Hendricks of Indiana to vote against the nominations, but Mr Seymour of Vermont had told him he thought there was not much in the Report— Mr Edwards, Senator from Connecticut brought two Letters concerning Timothy Savage, Surveyor and Inspector of the Customs at Middletown; appointed during the recess, nominated to the Senate, and confirmed by them, but whose permanent Commission has not yet been forwarded to him. These Letters affirm that as long since as in 1790, Savage was convicted of smuggling, including perjury, upon his own plea of guilty, on indictment in the Circuit Court as appears upon the Records of the Court itself— I promised to withhold the Commission until the charges shall have been investigated— Messrs.Brent and Gurley came to recommend the appointment of Fulwar Skipwith, as Postmaster at New Orleans, in the place of Coll Croghan appointed Inspector General— I told them I had been much disposed in favour of Mr Skipwith until the Postmaster General had shewn me a Letter from General Jackson containing very severe charges, against him, for his conduct at the time of the British invasion, and when he was President of the Senate of Louisiana. They said it was all the effect of prejudice in General Jackson, and wished to see the Letter; for which I referred them to the Postmaster General. He afterwards called himself, and mentioned the several persons recommended for the Office: said Brent and Gurley had asked him for a copy of that Letter; which he had declined giving— Nor did he seem disposed to favour Skipwith— Mr Bowie employed at the Navy-Yard came to solicit the appointment of Naval Store-keeper here if that place should be vacated by Coll. Brearley as he expected— Gilbert C Russell came to solicit the restoration of his friend Coll. W. King to the Army; which I told him could not at present be done— He said King was beyond all question the first military man that was in the service— I told him that King’s order upon which a deserting Soldier, had been shot in cold blood, while imploring to be tried by a Court Martial, was too much for me to get over—and other charges of which he had been convicted upon his trial had been nearly as bad— General Brown introduced Lieutenant Armstrong, Son of the General of that name; and Mr M’Kean of H.R.U.S. introduced a Pennsylvanian, whose name in the margin is perhaps not correct.
18. VI. Walk to the Capitol— Met G. Sullivan as I was returning home.

The day was almost entirely absorbed by visitors— Mr Lowry brought me a single confirmation of a nomination by the Senate— Mr Southard and Mr. Rush were both here twice— Southard having been for several days much detained at home by the illness of his wife, who is now relieved by the birth yesterday of a daughter— He brought a Letter from Captain David Porter; requesting that as his term of suspension from the service is about expiring his leave of absence might be prolonged, for six Months more— I saw no reason for refusing it; but thought it might be suggested to him, that it would then be my wish to employ him in active service— Mr Rush, brought and left with me several Letters— He had a Report from the Register of the Treasury upon the Resolution of the House of Representatives calling for a statement of monies received by Mr Monroe for public services before he was President, but part of this Letter from the Register referred to his own mistake in a statement of my Accts last Winter—which being entirely out of place in answering this call, I advised that the Register should revise his Report— I gave Mr Rush the Letters containing the charge against
Timothy Savage, and requested him to make known the charge to the party accused, and call upon him to answer it. The Secretary at War, brought the first draught of a new Treaty with the Creek Indians, upon which he has nearly agreed with them through the Medium of Governor Cass— Every attempt to prevail upon them to cede the whole of their lands within the State of Georgia has proved abortive; and after the deputation yesterday left the War-Office, under the impression that the Negotiation was definitively broken off, the first Chief of the Deputation Opoethle Yeholo, attempted last evening to commit suicide. This morning however a new effort had been made, and they have consented, not to depart from the line of the Chatahoochy; but to take a more western branch of it than they had hitherto been willing to yield— Mr Barbour said this was all he could expect to do; and advised to conclude with them on these terms— I agreed that he should— I read over his draft, and urged the expediency of some supplementary provisions, for the benefit of the other portion of the Creek tribe the friends of Mackintosh, which Governor Barbour promised to introduce. Mr Knight of the Senate and Mr Isacks of the House brought me an enrolled bill of appropriation for payment of the pensioners, which I immediately examined, approved, signed and sent back to the House— Mr Thompson and Mr Hayden called together. Hayden left with me a Memorial signed by several persons belonging to the Genesee district, remonstrating against the appointment of Jesse Hawley the Collector again because they alledge that he has neglected his family; and because his wife has filed a complaint against him in equity; for adultery, which was taken ex professo, for want of a trial or appearance— I told Mr Hayden that however strongly I disapproved such conduct, it had never been the practice for the Government to inquire into the private concerns of their Officers. Official conduct was the only subject of investigation which we could undertake— MessrsJ. Bailey, J. W. Taylor, and D. Webster spent part of the Evening with me—
19. V. Walk to Capitol Square.

Hodgson came to say he was preparing to embark for Algiers; and to thank me for the opportunity of going there— My purpose is to attach to each of the Consulates in Barbary a young man for three years; to learn the Turkish and Arabick languages, and the Lingua Franca—with a view to have persons among our public Officers versed in those languages— I have desired that Hodgson might be one of these persons, as he has a fondness and a facility for acquiring languages, quite uncommon. The other three Students of this Class I propose to select among the Midshipmen of the Squadron in the Mediterranean. Mr George Graham came to speak concerning the sale of Lands in Missouri for the erection of Iron works— Proposes to sell alternate Sections; which I approved— Mr M’Kean member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, introduced Mr Moore— Judge Cranch brought and shewed me a large Collection of
drawings by his Son John; who has a remarkable talent for that art. General Metcalfe introduced to me Dr Holt, of Kentuckey, and recently from thence— Mr Daniel Brent mentioned the Resolution of the House of Representatives calling for the Correspondence with the British Government concerning the Northwest Coast, and thought there had been none of late which could be communicated— Mr Lowry had given him one printed copy of the Report of the Senate’s Committee of Foreign Relations against the Panama Mission— Their order is only to furnish to the Department of State 25 Copies, of the papers from that Department, printed by their orders— Mr George Hay is here for the purpose of settling his Accounts as District Attorney. He mentioned to me the claims for allowances which he makes, to extinguish a small balance for which he has been left accountable— But he said the real and only question was whether he was to be held accountable for Wilson Cary Nicholas’s debts as Collector of Norfolk— Mr Nahum Ward came to take leave—being about to return to the Western Country— But he signified to me without hesitation, that he would either accept any respectable Office to go abroad, or any profitable Land-Office at home— The influenza is extremely prevalent in the City; both my Sons are affected with it; and this day I found myself suffering under it.
20. V:15— Walk to the Capitol-Square— My cold severe.

George Johnson came to solicit a place as a Clerk in one of the Departments, to which I assured him I should in no case recommend him. Mr Graham came concerning the Sales of certain public Lands, and the appointment of certain Land Officers— Mr White brought new complaints against the Collector at Pensacola Hamilton; and recommendations for appointments to some other Offices in Florida— I mentioned to him that the payment of Messrs.Gibson and Simon would depend upon Congress’s making an appropriation for that purpose— Captain Riley is an Officer in the Army who is urgently praying for a brevet rank which he had declined during the late War— I told him I should give all proper consideration to the supposed claim; but suggested the difficulty of granting brevets at this time. Mr Marks the Senator from Pennsylvania came I conclude for a visit of amusement and Governor Cass, to introduce Captain Douglas one of the Teachers at West-Point just from the place; Letcher came under much excitement, upon learning that several of the Kentucky Delegation had joined in a written recommendation of General John Adair to the appointment of Chargé d’Affaires to Peru— Adair is about 67 years of age; and has held many Offices: the last of which was that of Governor of Kentucky— He never was fit for any diplomatic appointment; and is now fit for nothing— But about half the Kentucky Delegation have nevertheless Warranted him for service— Letcher most earnestly remonstrated against his appointment; which he said would have the worst possible political effect in Kentucky— This is precisely what is wanted by those who recommend him— Letcher intimated there was another person in Kentucky whose appointment would be very agreeable; but I reminded him that Kentucky had already more than her proportion of those appointments; and that
other parts of the Union claimed also their share. Mr Dorsey came with a warm recommendation of a Mr Hebb for an appointment in any one of the Departments— Mr Clay advised a communication of documents concerning the projected mission to Panama, to the House of Representatives— He was confident of a very decided majority of that house in favour of the Mission— He believed there would also be a majority of the Senate favourable to it— But there appeared to be a lingering in that body, and the report of their Committee against the mission which would be made public could only be answered by a counter-report or an open debate in the house— If the papers should be communicated to them, they would refer them to their Committee of Foreign Relations and whatever the disposition of the Chairman of that Committee Mr Forsyth might be, a majority of the Committee were friendly to the Administration, and Everett would be glad to make a Counter Report to that of Mr Tazewell— I told Mr Clay I would reflect upon the subject; but I thought it might be better to wait for a call from the House, than to send the papers to them without it—which would have the appearance of an appeal from the Senate to the House, and would be offensive to the Senate— Governor Barbour came to say that he had agreed upon a Treaty with the Creek Deputation, the Chatahoochy to be the boundary. He spoke also of the annual Report from West Point, by which 15 of the Cadets are reported deficient—and to be dismissed from the School— Among them Forsyth, a youth whose father was killed in the late War, and whom the Legislature of North-Carolina had undertaken to advocate— Also a Son of Commodore Rodgers— Mr Rush had a new Report from the Register of the Treasury, concerning monies paid to Mr Monroe—and Mr Southard brought me Captain David Porter’s Letter to President Monroe of 26. October 1824. and his Southard’s Report to Mr Monroe in answer to it—he left them with me to read and determine whether they should be sent to the House of Representatives with the papers relating to Porter’s trial— We had company to dine Willis Alston, John Barney, C. C. Cambreleng, Matthew St. Clair Clark, William Deitz, Captain D. B. Douglas, John Holmes, Jonathan Jennings, Joseph Lawrence, John M’lean, P.M.G. and Mrs William M’lean, Orange Merwin, John Miller, John Reed, S. L. Southard, Andrew Stewart, L. W. Tazewell, James Trezvant, John Varnum, Captain Lewis Warrington, and William Wilson—with the family and Miss Mease 29 at table; but Charles was so ill with the influenza, that he could not come to table— There had been invited who came not W. C. Bradley, D. Bouligny, Mrs and 3 Misses, W. N. Edwards, Joseph and Mrs Gist, George Hay, James and Mrs M’Ilvaine, George M Owen, George Peter, and perhaps W. Wilson— Some of the company failed from illness and some from indisposition— The influenza so generally prevails that Mr Tazewell told me the Senate had some difficulty yesterday in forming a Quorum— I was much indisposed with the influenza myself— I sent this Morning a Message to H.R. with Reports of Secy of War and Commr of Land-Office on Leases of Lead Mines and Salines.
21. IV:30. To the Capitol.

Elisha Smith came to complain that the money which he had sent to take out a Patent in September 1823 had been received at the Patent Office, and lost— The amount he admitted however had been returned to him— And he had taken out a Patent now for a tincture to eradicate Corns; a vial of which I took of him— Jamison came to solicit a Clerk’s Office— Stewart and Lawrence to introduce Baird, Moore and Stockton, all visitors from Pennsylvania. The Secretary of War brought the draft of a new Treaty with the Creeks which Governor Cass has assisted him in negotiating— Although far from being satisfied with it, I believe it the best that we can obtain. I authorized Governor Barbour, to close with it— Mr George Hay came to apologize for having mistaken my invitation to dine here, as for next Tuesday, instead of yesterday; and he promised to come on Tuesday— General Brown brought and introduced General Bogardus of New-York, as a particular and intimate friend of Governor Clinton. Lieutenant Elmsley is a son of Mrs Elmsley the Sister of Mr W. N. Boylston, and brought me a Letter of Introduction from him— Mr Brent called to mention that Mr Clay had been taken suddenly quite ill this morning; so that he was obliged to leave the office and go home— Lieutenant Weaver brought me a copy of his Memorial, upon which he wished me to make a decision immediately. He was Cashiered by the Sentence of a Court Martial; and now prays to be restored to his service, and if possible to his rank— Miss Mease dined abroad, and came home ill with the influenza, with which both my Sons and myself are also afflicted— Evening in my chamber, writing.
22. V:30. To the Capitol. Sun rose 7:9. behind high chimnies. Same as 19. Novr.

Read for Consolation—“In God I have put my trust, I will not fear what flesh can do unto me. Every day they wrest my words: all their thoughts are against me for evil.[”] Psalm 56.4.5 Heard Mr Little from Psalm 58.11. [“]So that a man shall say, verily there is a reward for the righteous: verily he is a God that judgeth in the Earth.”— After the Service I called to see Mr Clay, who is yet much indisposed— Found General Harrison and Mr C. Dorsey there. In the afternoon I heard at St. John’s Church Mr M’Ilvaine, from Philippians 3.8. [“]Yea, doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord.” This person is now Chaplain and Professor of Moral Philosophy at West Point; and is here only upon a visit— There is eloquence in his composition, but great affectation in his delivery. A Vice in the indulgence of which he is continually growing worse— Evening visit from B. W. Crowninshield, Clement Dorsey and John Barney— They spoke of the Elections pending of a Senator from New-York— A Senator from Maryland in the place of Edward Lloyd, who has resigned, and a member of the House of Representatives in the place of John Randolph, elected to the Senate— So great is the excitement in Virginia against the present Administration that W B. Giles who is publishing inflammatory papers in the Richmond Enquirer, has been brought forward as a Candidate, although not an Inhabitant of the District, and it is said has very probably been elected— This fermentation does not extend however beyond the State of Virginia— There are other sources of discontent in other quarters; but none which now appear to menace the public tranquility— The Senator for Maryland will be a Coll. Chambers: and N Sanford from New-York.
23. V:30. Capitol Square.

Mr Southard came with a Report, and voluminous papers containing the proceedings of the Court-Martials on the trials of Captain Stewart, and of Lieutenants Sands and Hunter—all to be sent to the House of Representatives in answer to a Call. Mr Southard said he had not included with the papers the trial of Lieutenant Sands on board Ship, the proceedings of the Court having been disapproved by Captain Stewart, not supposing them embraced in the Call— I thought so too; and observed that if they were wanted they could be specially called for and then sent. Mr Brashears came with a subscription paper for publishing a volume of Poems— I declined to subscribe but promised to take the book— Mr White the Delegate from Florida, brought and introduced a Mr Mitchell, fresh from that Territory, and by his Speech not long from Ireland. Barbour came with J. P. Duval, a brother of the Governor of Florida, and a Candidate for Office in the same Territory— Perhaps of Collector of Pensacola, and I referred him to the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr Handy came to solicit employment of which he is in great want— Mr Tucker came to take leave. He is going to-morrow Morning on his return to the University— He appears to regret his exchange of a political for a literary career— Evening spent writing.
24. V:30. Capitol Square— Ground powdered with Snow.

Captain Hohnstein is one of the Military Officers, left consequently upon the fall of Napoleon, to seek his fortunes in the world. He came to this Country hoping to obtain a Commission in our Army, and finding this impracticable, he is seeking the means of going to offer his services to the Mexican or Colombian Republics. He says he has put himself upon the charity of the foreign Ministers here without much success— Mr Brent came to speak of the appointment of a Commercial Agent at St. John’s Porto-Rico— I desired him to make out a Commission for a person named Simmons recommended by J. Wurts, the member of the House from Philadelphia. There is a Resolution of H.R. calling for the Correspondence with Great Britain, not already communicated, relating to the North-West Coast of America— Mr Clay had sent me a Report in answer to that Resolution, that there was no such Correspondence which could be communicated without inconvenience to the public interest, because the Negotiations concerning it were yet pending and unfinished, but I thought it would be more expedient to send to the House, my Letter of Instructions to Mr Rush, and his Report of Conferences with the British Plenipotentiaries on this subject— I desired Mr Brent to have copies of them made for this purpose— Mr Miller came to introduce Dr Sutherland, who is a member of the Senate of Pennsylvania, and just from Harrisburg— I had seen him at Philadelphia. Edward Ingersoll came with them— Mr White came to solicit some appointment for Mr Van Wyck, a member of the two last
Congresses from the District of New-York now represented by Dr White; but who by an indiscreet removal into Virginia, has in the course of one year fallen into ruin. Mr M’Ilvaine is here upon a short visit from West-Point— Mr William Brent came with his brother Daniel to recommend Judge Cranch’s eldest Son William for a Clerkship in any of the Public Offices. The judge is about removing from Alexandria to this City— Mr Clay called to mention that Baron Stackelberg, Charge d’Affaires from Sweden has just returned from a leave of absence of nearly two years, and wished to be presented to me— I desired Mr Clay to inform the Baron that I would receive him at the Drawing Room to-morrow— I had directed the same notice to be given to Mr Vaughan the British Minister who had requested permission to present Mr Ousley, his Secretary of Legation recently arrived— Mr Hay spoke, as altogether certain—that the nominations for the Panama Mission would be advised and consented to by the Senate— I am not equally sangwine. Governor Barbour informed me that the new Treaty with the Creek deputation was prepared for signature. I authorized him to sign it, and it was accordingly signed at the War-Office— I had been anxiously desirous that it should also be signed by the other deputation from the Mackintosh party; but the others would not suffer them to join in the Treaty— Governor Barbour said they would sign a separate paper to be annexed to the Treaty— Ample provision is made for them in it; and by terms adjusted with themselves— Mr Rush read me a note from Mr Webster, Chairman of a Committee of the House of Representatives, upon the part of the Session Message relating to the Organization of the Executive Departments; asking his views with regard to the condition of the Treasury Department— Mr Rush said that the Department required some additional organization; but he had not yet sufficient experience in it to be prepared with a plan—and this would be the purport of his answer, which I approved. Mr Webster has sent a similar note to the Heads of all the Departments; but in the proposed Bill for the Establishment of a Home Department, the duties to be assigned to it will be taken almost entirely from the Departments of State and of War. Mr Rush gave me some particulars of his last Negotiation in England, and spoke of the great extent and compass of the Instructions given him for it— Mr Stratford Canning’s temper in the management of it was such as I had generally witnessed it here— Mr Rush says Count Lieven told him that Mr Canning had displayed the same tenacious, irritable, captious, and unconciliating disposition in Russia— Lieutenant Elmsley dined with us. Mr George Hay had promised the same, but sent an excuse this morning; alledging indisposition.
25. V:30. Capitol Square. Fahrenheit 12.

Our Coachman John Cook was found this morning dead in his bed. I sent immediately for Dr Huntt, and he not being at home, for Dr Lovell— They both came very soon, but the Spirit had fled, and nothing could be done to restore life— He had a pulmonary complaint, but was not confined—had driven the Carriage yesterday, and had been at a tavern last evening till between ten and eleven O’Clock; eating raw oysters and drinking beer— He had been in our service since last Winter, and was a safe and skilful driver, with a quiet and sober disposition— We have suffered a loss by his death; and its suddenness is a fresh lesson of the frail and feeble tenure of
human life— May we all lay it duly to heart, and remember to be also ready! Genl Van Rensselaer came and brought me a printed pamphlet from the author; being a Memorial upon the upward forces of fluids, by Edmond Charles Genet; once Minister Plenipotentiary from the French Republic to this Government; but for the last thirty years an inhabitant of the State of New-York. Mr W. Findlay Senator, and Daniel H. Miller a Member of the House of Representatives came to urge a re-nomination to the Senate of Lieutenant Wolbert, cashiered by the Sentence of a Court-Martial. I told them I would deliberately consider of the subject. Mr Wickliffe of Kentucky came and introduced to me an acquaintance of his from that State— Coll. R. Jones the Adjutant General brought me an Army Register corrected, with all the latest appointments— He spoke also of my nomination of D Bissell as Coll. of the second Regiment of Artillery, and said he heard the Senate would confirm the appointment, and give him retrospective rank to the time when they think he should have been appointed—in which case Jones said he hoped the principle would also be applied to him— I said, I thought the Senate had no power to look back, and antedate Bissells Commission; and could only simply advise and consent to the nomination as made, or refuse their advice and consent— From the Newspaper of this Morning it appears that Coll. W. King for whose re-appointment I have been so much importuned, recently died at Mobile. Governor Barbour brought me the Treaty which he signed yesterday with the deputation of the Creek Indians— Those of the Mackintosh party refused to sign it, unless we would engage to pay for improvements on lands not relinquished by them; and because they alledge the Treaty imports reproach to Mackintosh— Fourth Drawing-room for the Season. Crowell told me that Forsyth had prevented the Mackintosh party of Indians from signing their assent to the new Treaty— Mills told me the Senate had postponed till next Wednesday the discussion upon the Panama Mission— Miner of Pennsylvania this day offered in the House, one of them approving of that Mission— But the Resolutions are laid on the table. Baron Stackelberg, Chargé d’Affaires from Sweden presented himself upon his return to his post; and Mr Vaughan the British Minister presented Mr Ousley as Secretary of Legation.
26. VI— To the Capitol. Fahrenheit 14. Potowmack frozen

My Son John attended the funeral of our Coachman John Cook, who was buried from this house at eleven O’Clock this morning— The funeral service was performed by the Presbyterian Clergyman Mr Baker. Mr Lowry brought me three Resolutions from the Senate confirming nominations. Mr Cook left with me a recommendation signed by almost all the members of the Legislature of the State of Illinois, of Nathanael Pope as a Judge of the Supreme Court— The Bill for appointing three additional Judges of that Court, being likely to pass both Houses of Congress. Cook enquired also for some papers of Mr. N. Edwards which I was not able to find— Mr Anderson came with another Memorial from New-York praying for a pardon for Amedey. Mr Rush had Letters
from the Collector at New-York, answering Instructions which had been sent him, to cause any of the ships of Edward Thomsons expected from China, which might arrive at New-York to be seized, in order to secure the payment of the monies due from him to the United States. He answers that the District Attorney upon being consulted, knows of no process by which the ships could be seized, and he asks for further Instructions— Mr Rush had also a Letter from Thomson himself; complaining that he is yet kept in close prison, and renewing the solicitation to be discharged— He has signed in triplicates, orders to the Captains of his Ships to come in to Philadelphia, and not to go elsewhere— These are to be sent out by Revenue Cutters to meet the ships as they will be coming upon the Coast. Mr Barbour the Secretary of War brought me two Indian Treaties, one with the Kansas and the other with the Great and Little Osages consenting to the making of a Road from Missouri to Mexico. He also took back his Report upon the new Treaty with the Creek Deputation, to make some alteration in it. Mr Sutherland came and took leave— Going to-morrow upon his return to Harrisburg— He is a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature now in Session. He intimated a disposition altogether friendly to the administration of the General Government, and said in confidence that he had some reason to believe, Mr Steele the Collector intended to resign shortly— If he should resign before the 4th. of March, Sutherland recommended the appointment of John Andrew Schulze, the present Governor of Pennsylvania in his place. It would be the most popular appointment for the Administration that could be made; but it should not be delayed till March; because at the beginning of that Month, there would be a Convention at Harrisburg to nominate a Governor for the next three years— Schulze would be nominated for re-election and would be re-elected by a considerable majority; but if he should be appointed Collector before then, they would have an opportunity to agree upon another Candidate. I asked him who that would probably be. He said probably some Western man. I told him I had a very favourable opinion of Govr. Schulze’s character, and in the event of the Collector’s Office becoming vacant I would bear this recommendation in mind— Mr Talbot paid a morning visit; and Mr John Williams who is soon going to Guatemala—and who asked for advice with regard to his proceeding.
27. VI. To the Capitol— Fahrenheit 18.

Mr Graham made a Report in answer to a Call from the House of Representatives, for information concerning the Leases of Lead Mines and Salt-Springs— There has already been a Report from the War Department respecting the Lead Mines; that upon the Salt Springs is from the Land-Office; and there remains still one from the Treasury Department, of the Money received upon these Leases— I sent the papers to the Treasury for this purpose, and desired Mr Rush to call to it the attention of the Comptroller— Mr Rush brought me a bundle of papers concerning the case of the Collector at Pensacola Hamilton— Mr Bassett is Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives on the Monument for Washington— He wrote me some time since to ask information concerning a statement made to him in a Letter from G. W. P. Custis, that a sort of verbal promise had been made to Mrs Washington that her remains should be deposited with those of her husband in the Capitol— Mr Bassett now came for an answer. I told him I had written to my father, enclosing a copy both of his Letter to me, and of G. W. P. Custis’s to him & I had
as yet no answer from my father, but was in daily expectation of receiving one which when received I would immediately communicate to him— The Secretary of War brought his Report on the new Creek Treaty revised, and asked if I could send it in to the Senate this day— I said it was too late; and that with the Treaty, I wished to send a Message assigning the Reasons, upon which it had been concluded, and for setting aside the Treaty of 12 Feby last— I should be glad to consult the members of the administration upon the message before sending it in— I would prepare it between this and Monday Morning, and I asked him to notify the members of the administration to meet here on Monday at Noon, which he promised— General Brown, called to consult me with regard to the propriety of his first visiting the foreign Ministers— He said that Mr Monroe had advised him to visit the Ministers Plenipotentiary; but no other foreign Agents of inferior rank. He had of consequence not visited Mr Jackson, the British Commissioner under the Slave-indemnity Commission— I said Mr Monroe had advised him properly, and I thought he should continue upon the same principle— There was no occasion for him to visit Mr Jackson, who was not a Minister Plenipotentiary, though much inclined to consider himself so. The General expatiated also much upon the politics of the State of New-York, and the prospects and purposes of Governor Clinton— Mr Alfred H Powell came as a visitor to introduce a Mr Lambert from Virginia. Mr W. C. Bradley came to say he was going on a visit of a few weeks, home in Vermont. He spoke of the appointment of James Fisk as Collector at Allburg, and of his wish that the nomination should be suspended until his return, about the 20th. of February— He told me that Mr Clay had decided against the claim of Governor Van Ness, as Commissioner under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— Bradley said that all was going on very quietly here, but at Albany there was a very heavy intrigue going on, into which Mr Van Buren was disposed to enter— Mr Clinton was to keep a very smooth face towards the General Government until his own re-election as Governor of New-York next November, after which he was to come out at the head of an Opposition to the Administration of the General Government. Bradley professes the art of political hoaxing— I asked him to dine with me, and he did. Mr Clay was here; and said it was reduced to a certainty that there would be a vote of at least 31. Senators to confirm the nominations for the Panama Mission, perhaps 36 If they exceed 25 I shall be agreeably disappointed. I am very doubtful even of a majority— Robert Mills, a man from Wythe County Virginia came with some claim at the War Department, but principally as he told me to see me— I referred him to the Department— We had company to dine. Robert Allen of Tennesee; and MrsSamuel BellJohn M. Berrien, W. C. Bradley, Lewis Condict, and Mrs.Nehemiah Eastman, H H. Gurley and Mrs.Joseph Healey, Samuel D. Ingham— James JohnsonR. P. Letcher, Archibald M’Neill, H. C. Martindale. John Mattocks. Elijah H. Mills. Robert Orr, T. H. Porter, John Taliaferro, Robert Taylor. Elisha. Miss Whittlesey. Charles A. Wickliffe. Austin E. Wing— Silas Wood and William S. Young. There were
invited who came not, Miss Berrien and Miss Fay, Richard M. Johnson, James Meriwether and John Randolph—and George Hay—
28. VI. To the Capitol— Fog.

Mr Powell, member of the House of Representatives came and introduced his brother, who is from Winchester— Mr Adams solicited the admission at West-Point, as a Cadet of his brother Dan Adams’s son— Dan Adams himself served during the late War, a Campaign in Canada; and after one of the battles was missing, and has never since been heard of. From some uncertain rumours, his family have entertained hopes that he had been taken prisoner by the Indians and was yet living— Last year, Mr P. Adams applied for Letters to the Governor of Canada, with a view to circulate an advertisement offering a reward of 1000 dollars, for any information concerning Dan Adams if alive; but nothing satisfactory has been obtained— This youth for whom admission at West-Point is now solicited, is about sixteen, and has been since the disappearance of his father, maintained by his uncle Parmenio— I expressed my wish that the young man should obtain the appointment; but mentioned the necessity that it should go through the regular channel of the War Department— Messrs.Sloan, Vance and Dwight called as morning visitors; Dwight spoke of the Panama Mission which has now become a subject of discussion in the House of Representatives— Mr Webster spent an hour of the Evening with me— Mr Clay had called to recommend Mr Henry R. Warfield, a member of the last Congress, as a special messenger to be sent to R. C. Anderson at Bogota, to direct him to proceed to the Sea-Coast, on the way to Panama— I thought it would be most advisable to wait until it should be ascertained whether the Senate will confirm the nominations; of which I am still in doubt— I spoke to Webster of the Resolution, offered by Ingham, and referred to the Judiciary Committee of the House, of which Webster is Chairman; respecting the official conduct of C. J. Ingersoll— The Committee have not received his defence; but they are better informed of the facts on which the charge is grounded, than they were upon Mr Ingham’s uncandid Statement in the House.
29. VI. To the Western Market— Thick fog.

Heard Mr Little from 1. Corinthians 3.2. “I have fed you with milk; and not with meat: for hitherto ye were not able to bear it, neither yet now are ye able.” The discourse was unusually dull— Walked home with Mr Crowninshield. In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker, from Luke 18.1. “And he spake a parable unto them, to this end, that men ought always to pray, and not to faint.” There is in Mr Baker much more fervour of intention than efficiency of performance. He labours to be eloquent, but cannot devise thoughts to give significancy to the multitude of his words— Prayer is one of the comforts of a Christian’s life— Continual prayer, is a duty and an enjoyment— Importunate prayer seems to be recommended by the Parable in Luke 18— Its tendency, frequently and unceasingly repeated, is to fix the mind in uprightness, and to keep one always reminded of the obligations of our duty— Besides my usual occupations I prepared a draft of a Message to be sent to the Senate with the new Creek Treaty.
30. VI. Capitol. Snow till noon— Cleared away cold at Night.

Mr. M’Kee is a Member of the House of Representatives from Alabama. He came to recommend William Crawford for the appointment of District Judge in that State; in the place of Charles Tait who resigns. But W. R. King one of the Senators, and G. M. Owen another of the Representatives are vehemently opposed to the appointment of Crawford. They recommend James Dillet— And in proportion to their earnestness against Crawford, is his tenaciousness in his favour. I mentioned to him that I had received recommendations in favour of Israel Pickens the late Governor of the State; at which he appeared to be surprized— Cabinet Meeting, from Noon till four O’Clock. I read my draft of a Message to be sent in to the Senate with the new Creek Treaty— The Report of the Secretary of War; and the Treaty itself— Several alterations were suggested by Mr Clay to the Message which I adopted— Some alterations were also proposed to the Report of the Secretary of War, and Governor Barbour took it away to make them— The principal question discussed was whether all the Correspondence with the Governor of Georgia; and all the controversial papers, of Governor Troup, J. CrowellJ. P. Andrews and General Gaines should be communicated to the Senate with the Treaty or not— Governor Barbour was desirous that they should not be sent; thinking that withholding them much angry discussion may be obviated— I assented to the omission, wishing that the whole Transaction might be consummated according to the views of Governor Barbour— A principal motive for this is that Governor Barbour having been intimately confidential with the Georgians, they will be less disposed to violence against a measure entirely his, than if it came from other persons— Mr Clay rather inclined to the opinion that the whole body of Documents should be sent with the Treaty; but acquiesced in the suggestion, that if any member of the Senate should wish to see the correspondence, he could move a Call for it; and it could be immediately sent— It was agreed on all sides that if the Senate advise and consent to the Ratification of the Treaty, when sent to both Houses of Congress for the Appropriations to carry it into effect, all the documents must be sent— But they would not be likely to produce so much excitement or debate, as at this time before the decision of the Senate upon the Treaty— Mr Clay thought the new Treaty, a much more disadvantageous one to the United States than the former; and I have no doubt it will be so represented, but I am not of that opinion— Governor Barbour spoke of certain accounts of a General War and of a Mr Baley for supplies furnished to the Mackintosh Indians; which Genl. Gaines had disallowed, and upon which an appeal from his decision is before the Secretary of War— I thought they had been properly disallowed; as the evidence exhibited strong marks of imposition attempted upon the United States— Mr Rush remained some time after the meeting broke up. I sent a Message to S.U.S. N. 21. with two Indian Treaties for Roads— Mr E. J. Coale of Baltimore dined and spent part of the Evening with us.
31. VI. To the Church. Sun rose at 7— In same line as 11. November. Fahrenheit 11.

I sent a Message to the Senate with the new Creek Treaty N. 22. and one to the House of Representatives, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and the Correspondence with Great Britain relating to territorial boundary on the Northwest Coast of America— Mr Lowry brought me a Resolution of the Senate requesting information whether the Spanish Government have been apprized of our application to the Emperor of Russia for his interposition to prevail on Spain to recognize the Southern American Republics, and for any correspondence which has passed on that subject. Mr Vance Member of the House from Ohio came and introduced Mr Coffee of that State— Mr Rush the Secretary of the Treasury was here twice— Mentioned the Resignation of Captain Richards a Clerk in the Department, and the urgency with which Genl. Cocke, had pressed the appointment of a young man named Queen, in his place. Cook had told him two days ago that Richards would resign, if Queen could be appointed— Rush declined giving any promise. Nevertheless Richards has resigned—for which I told Mr Rush, I was confident, there was some very special reason— Mr Rush requested me to name some person to him for the place. I mentioned to him Mr Van Wyck the late member of Congress from Duchess County New-York, and Mr Ebenezer French, from whom I had received several very earnest solicitations. Mr Rush informed me that Mr S. H. Smith had returned from his mission to Philadelphia to investigate the recent extraordinary transactions at the Custom-house at that place. Mr Clay came and spoke of the call from the Senate, and said he had directed copies of the papers to be made out— He spoke also of the appointment of the Legislative Council for the Territory of Michigan— There are two acts of Congress, and one territorial act under which the election is made, and there is a question whether the Territorial Act is not contrary to the Laws of Congress. Out of 26 persons, having the highest numbers of the qualified votes of the inhabitant, the President is to nominate to the Senate 13. But the territorial Act, divided the Territory into Districts, and allowed the inhabitants of each District to vote only for a proportional number of the 26. The act of Congress authorised the Territorial Legislature to prescribe the manner of the Election— Under which authority they made the Districts— I told Mr Clay I doubted the legality of the territorial act, and must reflect further upon it. While with me Mr Clay received a Note from Mr Webster— A debate commenced this day in the House of Representatives, on two Resolutions, calling for papers relating to the proposed Mission to Panama— This is the first subject upon which a great effort had been made in both Houses to combine the discordant elements, of the Crawford and Jackson and Calhoun men into a united opposition, against the Administration— It is at an early stage of its progress; but has already become complicated, and admonishes me to proceed, with extreme circumspection. Mr Hunter came to solicit the vacant Clerkship in the Treasury Department— I told him he was late— James Johnson dined and spent part of the Evening with us— He is applying to be appointed Clerk of the Supreme Court U.S.
Day— As the last Month— My course of life is very regular; with deep anxieties, and oppressive responsibilities—but with comforts calling for boundless gratitude symbols
